content: I feel like I'm gradually getting a feel for things, but definitely still have big misunderstandings about the language. Thanks again for the help.
Tim Siegel has marked this topic as resolved.
Tim Siegel has marked this topic as unresolved.

Wait, so one last clarification if I may. fn foo() -> impl FooTrait is the only way to say that the func returns some type which implements FooTrait, but the caller can't know exactly which one? I'd gotten the impression that impl X is just a shorthand for a <X> ... where ... generic, but it seems to be a bit more complicated than that.

@Tim Siegel so one of my big regrets was I wasn't here in 2018 to argue against return position impl Trait and function parameter impl Trait having the same syntax - in a function parameter it does do exactly what you're saying
Alright. A minor bump to stub my toe on at worst. :-)
Tim Siegel has marked this topic as resolved.
By the way, this function is part of an exercise on https://exercism.org/tracks/rust/exercises/low-power-embedded-game which is a fun way to practice
